title: Google Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL unveiled - and they're much cheaper than expected

After months of anticipation, Google has finally unveiled its 2019 flagship smartphones - the Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL.

The smartphones have a number of impressive features, including dual lens rear cameras arranged in a square orientation, gesture controls, and a new and improved Google Assistant.

While rumours ahead of the launch suggested that the smartphones would have hefty price-tags, thankfully this isn’t the case.

Here’s everything you need to know about the Google Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL.

(Image: Google)

Release date

The smartphones were unveiled today during a Google event held in New York.

(Image: Google)

Thankfully there's not too long to wait to get your hands on one - It will be available in store from October 24.

Price

While rumours suggested that the Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL would likely start at around £739 and £869 respectively, thankfully they’re much cheaper than expected.

The Pixel 4 starts at £669, while the Pixel 4 XL starts at £829.

Colours

The new smartphones are available in three colours - Just Black, Clearly White, and a limited edition ‘Oh So Orange.’

Display

The Pixel 4 features a 5.7-inch screen, while the Pixel 4 XL is slightly bigger, with a 6.3-inch display.

In terms of display features, users can expect to enjoy Smooth Display at 90 Hz, Ambient EQ and Adaptive Colour Mode.

Another key feature is Face Unlock, which allows users to access their display simply by looking at it.

This will particularly come in handy given that Google has ditched the rear fingerprint scanner that has featured in all previous Pixel smartphones.

Design

Google appears to have taken a leaf out of Apple’s book with the design of the back of the smartphones.

(Image: Google)

The rear cameras are now housed in a square design in the top left of the device, along with a sensor and flash.

Meanwhile, the bottom of the back features a simple G logo, resulting in a sleek finish.

The front of the smartphone reveals a full bezel at the top, rather than a notch or hole-punch as most rivals have opted for.

Cameras

The Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL feature dual-lens rear cameras, comprised of a main 16MP lens and a 12.2MP telephoto lens.

Their front-facing camera is a single 16MP lens, which is house in the top bezel.

Photography fans will be happy to hear that Google has included several impressive camera features in the new smartphones, including dual exposure controls and Live HDR+.

(Image: Google)

One of the most impressive camera features is Night Sight, which helps you to take low light photos without a flash.

With Night Sight, users can capture high quality images of the night sky, including stars, planets and even galaxies!

Battery

One of the slightly more disappointing features is the battery - the Pixel 4 includes a 2,800 mAh battery, while the Pixel 4 Xl has a 3,700 mAh battery.

In comparison, the Samsung Galaxy S10 has a much more impressive 3,400mAh battery, while the S10+ has a whopping 4,100mAh battery.

(Image: Google)

However, the Pixel 4 and 4 XL do have an Adaptive Battery feature, which learns your favourite apps and reduces power consumed by ones you rarely use.

Motion Sense

One of the most exciting new features is what Google calls Motion Sense.

Motion Sense lets you use gestures to control the smartphone, without so much as touching it.

By simply waving your hand over the smartphone, you can skip songs, snooze alarms and silence calls!

This could be handy for using your smartphone in awkward situations, such as when exercising, cooking or in the shower.
description: Google has unveiled the Pixel 4 and Pixel 4 XL smartphones at an event in New York today
